title: World Food Day: India Ranks 120th On Global Hunger List, Pakistan Fares Better
text:
Every October 16 is celebrated as World Food Day, commemorating the formation of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. This year the focus is on food wastage, whether it is at home, or at the harvesting stage.

#Foodloss and #foodwaste are two sides of the same coin that need to be addressed concurrently. But, what is the difference between the two?



🎥Watch the video to find out 👇#FAOYouth #SOFA2019 pic.twitter.com/z9wUydeefx — FAO (@FAO) October 15, 2019

In a new report by the Global Hunger Index, which surveys 117 countries, India has slipped to the 120th place, way behind our neighbours such as Pakistan, Nepal and Bangladesh. Pakistan ranks at 94, Bangladesh at 88 and Nepal at 73. India is the lowest placed South Asian country.

The report states: "Because of its large population, India's Global Hunger Index indicator values have an outsized impact on the indicator values for the region... India's child wasting rate is extremely high at 20.8 per cent - the highest wasting rate of any country in this report for which data or estimates were available.”

Hunger in the modern world

To gather this data, it used four parameters - undernourishment; child wasting, or the share of children under five years who have a low weight for their age; child stunting, or the share of children under five years who have a low height for their age, and child mortality rate under five years.

“Hunger stubbornly persists in many countries and is actually increasing in others. Multiple countries have higher hunger levels now than in 2010, and approximately 45 countries are set to fail to achieve low levels of hunger by 2030,” said Concern Worldwide US CEO Colleen Kelly.

How to combat food wastage

If you’re wondering how you could your bit to combat food wastage, here are some easy ways.

- Store food correctly

Ensure that perishable foods are stored at the correct temperature in the fridge.

- Shop smartly, avoid bulk buying

To prevent food from going bad in your fridge, shop for produce that will last you two-three days only. You might think it is cumbersome, but you will actually end up saving more.

- Use leftovers smartly

Learn how to convert your leftover food into some new dishes. Boiled rice and veggies can be converted to a fried rice, sabzi can be stuffed into toasted sandwiches etc

- Take stock of what’s in your fridge

Before you go grocery shopping, take a look at what you already have and avoid repeats of milk, meat etc.
